page.title: 03BROCKET HALL - PART TWO
page.content: In 1805 William Lamb married the young Caroline Ponsonby, the only daughter of the Earl of Bessborough. She was born in 1785 and lived with her grandmother, Lady Spencer, at Devonshire House in London. At first the newly-weds were happy, but Lady Caroline lost her heart to Lord Byron, the poet. They became good friends but their friendship ended in 1813. She wrote her first novel called "Glenarvon" in which Byron was criticized. She kept it a secret from everyone except a governess, and worked by candlelight in Brocket Hall at the dead of night. When Byron read "Glenarvon" he made harsh remarks about it and soon the remarks were passed on to Lady Caroline. She stayed on at Brocket Hall in virtual solitude for the rest of her life.
